Our model estimates that, all else equal, for each

of the product being a nose pack are multiplied by 
0.4 (a.k.a. 100*(0.4-1)% = decrease of 60% in odds)

50

Model

Interpretation

Linear

y = ɑ + βx

1 unit change in x is associated with a β unit change in y

Linear-log

y = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect a β unit change in y

1% change in x is associated with a 0.01*β unit change in y

Log-linear

ln(y) = ɑ + βx

For a 1 unit change in x, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1 unit change in x is associated with a 100*(exp(β)-1)% change in y

Log-log

ln(y) = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1% change in x is associated with a β% change in y (
elasticity
)

Regression type review

58

Deriving interpretations

Step 1, Write the model
: log(y) = a+b*log(x)

Step 2, Define new variable for x
:
 x
new
 = x*e

Step 3, Define new variable for y
: log(y
new
) = a+b*log(x
new
)

Step 4, Plug in Step 2 to Step 3
:    log(y
new
) = a+b*log(x*e)

Step 5, Use Step 1 to Rewrite Step 4’s RHS in terms of y
: 


log(y
new

new

65

Model

Interpretation

Linear

y = ɑ + βx

1 unit change in x is associated with a β unit change in y

Linear-log

y = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect a β unit change in y

1% change in x is associated with a 0.01*β unit change in y

Log-linear

ln(y) = ɑ + βx

For a 1 unit change in x, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1 unit change in x is associated with a 100*(exp(β)-1)% change in y

Log-log

ln(y) = ɑ + β ln(x)

If x is multiplied by 
e
, we expect y to be multiplied by e
β

1% change in x is associated with a β% change in y (
elasticity
)

Regression type review

Squishing x with 
a log 
→
 
interpret by 
multiplying x by 
e (or think about 
% change in x)

How to decide on multivariable 
regression inputs

●
Start with a hypothesis of what “covariates” 
(inputs) are relevant


●
Exclude relevant covariates that are very collinear 
with other covariates in your model already (can 
check correlations)

How to decide on multivariable 
regression inputs

●
Start with a hypothesis of what “covariates” 
(inputs) are relevant


●
Exclude relevant covariates that are very collinear 
with other covariates in your model already (can 
check correlations)


●
Check your residual plots, just like before! (Look 
for randomness, use transformations as needed)

109

What variables to 
include/exclude?

●
Want to include any input (x) that might 
have 
some effect on output (y)


●
Don’t want to include input (x) that’s noise



110

What variables to 
include/exclude?

●
Want to include any input (x) that might 
have 
some effect on output (y)


●
Don’t want to include input (x) that’s noise


●
You can get both “
included
 variable bias” 
and 
“
excluded
 variable bias” – there’s no 
one-size-fits-all rule, but some guidelines...

111

Takeaways on multivariable regression inputs

●
Choose covariates that... 

○
make sense

○
aren’t redundant
 (i.e., aren’t collinear and 
don’t overfit the data)

○
allow you (with transformation) to get 
random-looking residual plots
